title: JavaOOPAbstractClasses - Q0001
text: What is an abstract class in Java?

options.text: A class that cannot be instantiated
A class that must have only abstract methods
A class that cannot have constructors
A class that must be final

explanation: An abstract class cannot be instantiated directly; it serves as a base for subclasses.

title: JavaOOPAbstractClasses - Q0002
text: Which keyword is used to declare an abstract class in Java?

options.text: abstract
interface
extends
implements

explanation: The 'abstract' keyword is used to declare an abstract class in Java.

title: JavaOOPAbstractClasses - Q0003
text: Which of the following is true about abstract classes?

options.text: They can have both abstract and concrete methods
They can only have abstract methods
They cannot have constructors
They cannot have variables

explanation: Abstract classes can have both abstract (unimplemented) and concrete (implemented) methods.

title: JavaOOPAbstractClasses - Q0004
text: Can an abstract class have a constructor?

options.text: Yes, it can
No, it cannot
Only if it has no abstract methods
Only if it is final

explanation: Abstract classes can have constructors, which are called when a subclass object is created.

title: JavaOOPAbstractClasses - Q0005
text: Which of the following is true about abstract methods?

options.text: They have no body
They must be implemented by subclasses
They are declared using the 'abstract' keyword
All of the above

explanation: Abstract methods have no body, must be implemented by subclasses, and are declared using 'abstract'.

title: JavaOOPAbstractClasses - Q0006
text: Can an abstract class implement an interface?

options.text: Yes, it can
No, it cannot
Only if it is final
Only if it has no abstract methods

explanation: An abstract class can implement an interface and may or may not provide implementations for its methods.

title: JavaOOPAbstractClasses - Q0007
text: Can an abstract class extend another abstract class?

options.text: Yes, it can
No, it cannot
Only if both have no abstract methods
Only if the parent is final

explanation: An abstract class can extend another abstract class and inherit its abstract and concrete methods.

title: JavaOOPAbstractClasses - Q0008
text: Can an abstract class have static methods?

options.text: Yes, it can
No, it cannot
Only if it has no abstract methods
Only if it is final

explanation: Abstract classes can have static methods because static methods belong to the class, not instances.

title: JavaOOPAbstractClasses - Q0009
text: Can an abstract class have final methods?

options.text: Yes, it can
No, it cannot
Only if it has no abstract methods
Only if it is final

explanation: Abstract classes can have final methods to prevent subclasses from overriding them.

title: JavaOOPAbstractClasses - Q0010
text: Can an abstract class be declared final?

options.text: No, because it cannot be subclassed
Yes, it can
Only if it has no abstract methods
Only if it is static

explanation: An abstract class cannot be declared final because it must be subclassed to implement its abstract methods.

title: JavaOOPAbstractClasses - Q0011
text: Can an abstract class have instance variables?

options.text: Yes, it can
No, it cannot
Only if they are static
Only if they are final

explanation: Abstract classes can have instance variables like any other class.

title: JavaOOPAbstractClasses - Q0012
text: Can an abstract class have a main() method?

options.text: Yes, it can
No, it cannot
Only if it is static
Only if it has no abstract methods

explanation: An abstract class can have a main() method and can be executed like any other class.

title: JavaOOPAbstractClasses - Q0013
text: Can an abstract class be instantiated directly?

options.text: No, it cannot
Yes, it can
Only if it has no abstract methods
Only if it is final

explanation: Abstract classes cannot be instantiated directly; they must be subclassed.

title: JavaOOPAbstractClasses - Q0014
text: Which of the following is true about abstract classes and interfaces?

options.text: Abstract classes can have constructors, interfaces cannot
Interfaces can have constructors
Both can have constructors
Neither can have constructors

explanation: Abstract classes can have constructors, but interfaces cannot.

title: JavaOOPAbstractClasses - Q0015
text: Which of the following is true about abstract classes and inheritance?

options.text: They must be extended by another class
They cannot be extended
They can only be implemented
They cannot have subclasses

explanation: Abstract classes must be extended by another class to provide implementations for abstract methods.

title: JavaOOPAbstractClasses - Q0016
text: Which of the following is true about abstract methods?

options.text: They cannot be static
They cannot be final
They cannot be private
All of the above

explanation: Abstract methods cannot be static, final, or private because they must be overridden.

title: JavaOOPAbstractClasses - Q0017
text: Which of the following is true about abstract classes and multiple inheritance?

options.text: A class can extend only one abstract class
A class can extend multiple abstract classes
Abstract classes support multiple inheritance
Abstract classes cannot be extended

explanation: Java supports single inheritance, so a class can extend only one abstract class.

title: JavaOOPAbstractClasses - Q0018
text: Which of the following is true about abstract classes and interfaces?

options.text: An abstract class can implement multiple interfaces
An abstract class can implement only one interface
An abstract class cannot implement interfaces
An abstract class must implement all interface methods

explanation: An abstract class can implement multiple interfaces and may choose not to implement all methods.

title: JavaOOPAbstractClasses - Q0019
text: Which of the following is true about abstract classes and polymorphism?

options.text: They support runtime polymorphism
They support compile-time polymorphism only
They cannot be used in polymorphism
They are static

explanation: Abstract classes support runtime polymorphism through method overriding.

title: JavaOOPAbstractClasses - Q0020
text: Which of the following is true about abstract classes and object creation?

options.text: They cannot be instantiated directly
They can be instantiated directly
They can be instantiated using 'new'
They can be instantiated if they have no abstract methods

explanation: Abstract classes cannot be instantiated directly; they must be subclassed.

title: JavaOOPAbstractClasses - Q0021
text: Which of the following is true about abstract classes and constructors?

options.text: Constructors in abstract classes are called when subclass objects are created
Constructors in abstract classes are never called
Abstract classes cannot have constructors
Constructors in abstract classes must be abstract

explanation: Constructors in abstract classes are called when subclass objects are created to initialize inherited members.

title: JavaOOPAbstractClasses - Q0022
text: Which of the following is true about abstract classes and method overriding?

options.text: Subclasses must override all abstract methods
Subclasses may ignore abstract methods
Abstract methods cannot be overridden
Abstract methods are automatically implemented

explanation: Subclasses must override all abstract methods of the abstract class unless they are also declared abstract.

title: JavaOOPAbstractClasses - Q0023
text: Which of the following is true about abstract classes and final methods?

options.text: Final methods in abstract classes cannot be overridden
Final methods in abstract classes must be overridden
Final methods in abstract classes are abstract
Final methods in abstract classes are static

explanation: Final methods in abstract classes cannot be overridden by subclasses.

title: JavaOOPAbstractClasses - Q0024
text: Which of the following is true about abstract classes and static methods?

options.text: Static methods in abstract classes can be called without creating an object
Static methods in abstract classes cannot exist
Static methods in abstract classes must be abstract
Static methods in abstract classes must be overridden

explanation: Static methods in abstract classes can be called using the class name without creating an object.

title: JavaOOPAbstractClasses - Q0025
text: Which of the following is true about abstract classes and access modifiers?

options.text: Abstract classes can have any access modifier
Abstract classes must be public
Abstract classes must be private
Abstract classes cannot have access modifiers

explanation: Abstract classes can have any access modifier: public, protected, or default.

title: JavaOOPAbstractClasses - Q0026
text: Which of the following is true about abstract classes and inheritance?

options.text: A subclass can extend only one abstract class
A subclass can extend multiple abstract classes
Abstract classes cannot be extended
Abstract classes can be extended by interfaces

explanation: Java supports single inheritance, so a subclass can extend only one abstract class.

title: JavaOOPAbstractClasses - Q0027
text: Which of the following is true about abstract classes and interfaces?

options.text: An abstract class can implement multiple interfaces
An abstract class can implement only one interface
An abstract class cannot implement interfaces
An abstract class must implement all interface methods

explanation: An abstract class can implement multiple interfaces and may choose not to implement all methods.

title: JavaOOPAbstractClasses - Q0028
text: Which of the following is true about abstract classes and polymorphism?

options.text: They support runtime polymorphism
They support compile-time polymorphism only
They cannot be used in polymorphism
They are static

explanation: Abstract classes support runtime polymorphism through method overriding.

title: JavaOOPAbstractClasses - Q0029
text: Which of the following is true about abstract classes and object creation?

options.text: They cannot be instantiated directly
They can be instantiated directly
They can be instantiated using 'new'
They can be instantiated if they have no abstract methods

explanation: Abstract classes cannot be instantiated directly; they must be subclassed.

title: JavaOOPAbstractClasses - Q0030
text: Which of the following is true about abstract classes and constructors?

options.text: Constructors in abstract classes are called when subclass objects are created
Constructors in abstract classes are never called
Abstract classes cannot have constructors
Constructors in abstract classes must be abstract

explanation: Constructors in abstract classes are called when subclass objects are created to initialize inherited members.

title: JavaOOPAbstractClasses - Q0031
text: Which of the following is true about abstract classes and method overriding?

options.text: Subclasses must override all abstract methods
Subclasses may ignore abstract methods
Abstract methods cannot be overridden
Abstract methods are automatically implemented

explanation: Subclasses must override all abstract methods of the abstract class unless they are also declared abstract.

title: JavaOOPAbstractClasses - Q0032
text: Which of the following is true about abstract classes and final methods?

options.text: Final methods in abstract classes cannot be overridden
Final methods in abstract classes must be overridden
Final methods in abstract classes are abstract
Final methods in abstract classes are static

explanation: Final methods in abstract classes cannot be overridden by subclasses.

title: JavaOOPAbstractClasses - Q0033
text: Which of the following is true about abstract classes and static methods?

options.text: Static methods in abstract classes can be called without creating an object
Static methods in abstract classes cannot exist
Static methods in abstract classes must be abstract
Static methods in abstract classes must be overridden

explanation: Static methods in abstract classes can be called using the class name without creating an object.

title: JavaOOPAbstractClasses - Q0034
text: Which of the following is true about abstract classes and access modifiers?

options.text: Abstract classes can have any access modifier
Abstract classes must be public
Abstract classes must be private
Abstract classes cannot have access modifiers

explanation: Abstract classes can have any access modifier: public, protected, or default.

title: JavaOOPAbstractClasses - Q0035
text: Which of the following is true about abstract classes and inheritance?

options.text: A subclass can extend only one abstract class
A subclass can extend multiple abstract classes
Abstract classes cannot be extended
Abstract classes can be extended by interfaces

explanation: Java supports single inheritance, so a subclass can extend only one abstract class.

title: JavaOOPAbstractClasses - Q0036
text: Which of the following is true about abstract classes and interfaces?

options.text: An abstract class can implement multiple interfaces
An abstract class can implement only one interface
An abstract class cannot implement interfaces
An abstract class must implement all interface methods

explanation: An abstract class can implement multiple interfaces and may choose not to implement all methods.

title: JavaOOPAbstractClasses - Q0037
text: Which of the following is true about abstract classes and polymorphism?

options.text: They support runtime polymorphism
They support compile-time polymorphism only
They cannot be used in polymorphism
They are static

explanation: Abstract classes support runtime polymorphism through method overriding.

title: JavaOOPAbstractClasses - Q0038
text: Which of the following is true about abstract classes and object creation?

options.text: They cannot be instantiated directly
They can be instantiated directly
They can be instantiated using 'new'
They can be instantiated if they have no abstract methods

explanation: Abstract classes cannot be instantiated directly; they must be subclassed.

title: JavaOOPAbstractClasses - Q0039
text: Which of the following is true about abstract classes and constructors?

options.text: Constructors in abstract classes are called when subclass objects are created
Constructors in abstract classes are never called
Abstract classes cannot have constructors
Constructors in abstract classes must be abstract

explanation: Constructors in abstract classes are called when subclass objects are created to initialize inherited members.

title: JavaOOPAbstractClasses - Q0040
text: Which of the following best describes an abstract class?

options.text: A class that cannot be instantiated and may contain abstract methods
A class that must be instantiated
A class that cannot have methods
A class that must be final

explanation: An abstract class cannot be instantiated and may contain abstract and concrete methods.

title: JavaOOPAbstractClasses - Q0041
text: Which of the following is true about abstract classes and method implementation?

options.text: They can have both implemented and unimplemented methods
They can only have unimplemented methods
They can only have implemented methods
They cannot have methods

explanation: Abstract classes can have both implemented (concrete) and unimplemented (abstract) methods.

title: JavaOOPAbstractClasses - Q0042
text: Which of the following is true about abstract classes and inheritance hierarchy?

options.text: They can be extended by concrete or abstract subclasses
They can only be extended by concrete subclasses
They cannot be extended
They can only be extended by interfaces

explanation: Abstract classes can be extended by both concrete and abstract subclasses.

title: JavaOOPAbstractClasses - Q0043
text: Which of the following is true about abstract classes and method visibility?

options.text: Abstract methods cannot be private
Abstract methods can be private
Abstract methods must be static
Abstract methods must be final

explanation: Abstract methods cannot be private because they must be overridden by subclasses.

title: JavaOOPAbstractClasses - Q0044
text: Which of the following is true about abstract classes and default methods?

options.text: They can have default implementations for methods
They cannot have default implementations
They must have all methods abstract
They cannot have any methods

explanation: Abstract classes can have default implementations for methods, unlike interfaces before Java 8.

title: JavaOOPAbstractClasses - Q0045
text: Which of the following is true about abstract classes and data members?

options.text: They can have instance and static variables
They cannot have variables
They can only have static variables
They can only have final variables

explanation: Abstract classes can have both instance and static variables.

title: JavaOOPAbstractClasses - Q0046
text: Which of the following is true about abstract classes and method overriding?

options.text: Subclasses must override all abstract methods
Subclasses may ignore abstract methods
Abstract methods cannot be overridden
Abstract methods are automatically implemented

explanation: Subclasses must override all abstract methods of the abstract class unless they are also declared abstract.

title: JavaOOPAbstractClasses - Q0047
text: Which of the following is true about abstract classes and object references?

options.text: They can be used to reference subclass objects
They cannot reference subclass objects
They can only reference abstract objects
They cannot be used in polymorphism

explanation: Abstract class references can be used to refer to subclass objects, enabling polymorphism.

title: JavaOOPAbstractClasses - Q0048
text: Which of the following is true about abstract classes and method implementation?

options.text: They can provide partial implementation
They must provide full implementation
They cannot provide any implementation
They must be empty

explanation: Abstract classes can provide partial implementation, leaving some methods abstract.

title: JavaOOPAbstractClasses - Q0049
text: Which of the following is true about abstract classes and interfaces?

options.text: Abstract classes can implement interfaces
Interfaces can extend abstract classes
Abstract classes cannot implement interfaces
Interfaces and abstract classes are identical

explanation: Abstract classes can implement interfaces and may or may not provide implementations for their methods.

title: JavaOOPAbstractClasses - Q0050
text: Which of the following best describes an abstract class in OOP?

options.text: A base class that defines common behavior and enforces implementation in subclasses
A class that cannot have methods
A class that must be final
A class that cannot be extended

explanation: An abstract class defines common behavior and enforces implementation of abstract methods in subclasses.
